unnormalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey into Ayurveda
normalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey into Ayurveda

unnormalised: The pace of Mumbai life is relentless. From catching the 07:15 local to juggling deadlines, it often felt like I was running on fumes. My doshas, as my grandmother, Aaji, would say, were completely out of whack. I knew I needed a change, something more profound than a weekend getaway. That's when I decided to explore Ayurveda.
normalised: The pace of Mumbai life is relentless. From catching the zero seven fifteen local to juggling deadlines, it often felt like I was running on fumes. My doshas, as my grandmother, Aaji, would say, were completely out of whack. I knew I needed a change, something more profound than a weekend getaway. That's when I decided to explore Ayurveda.

unnormalised: Growing up, Aaji always swore by Ayurvedic remedies. A concoction of turmeric and milk for a sore throat, neem paste for skin irritations – she had a solution for everything. But I'd dismissed it as old wives' tales. Now, faced with chronic fatigue and a persistent feeling of unease, I was ready to reconsider.

unnormalised: My journey started with a consultation at the Kerala Ayurveda Centre in Chembur. Dr. Nair, with his calm demeanor and insightful questions, spent a good hour understanding my lifestyle, diet, and medical history. He diagnosed a Vata imbalance and prescribed a personalized regimen that included Abhyanga (oil massage), Shirodhara (a steady stream of oil poured on the forehead), and a specific diet plan.

unnormalised: The Abhyanga, performed by a kind therapist named Lakshmi, was incredibly soothing. The warm sesame oil melted away the tension in my muscles, and I felt a sense of calm I hadn't experienced in years. The Shirodhara was equally transformative. Lying there with the warm oil trickling onto my forehead, I felt a deep sense of relaxation, almost meditative.

unnormalised: The dietary changes were initially challenging. Saying goodbye to my beloved spicy street food and embracing kitchari (a mung bean and rice dish) took some getting used to. But as the days turned into weeks, I noticed a significant shift. I felt more energetic, my digestion improved, and my sleep became deeper and more restful. I even managed to wake up before sunrise at 06:00 hrs a couple of times!

unnormalised: It's been three months since I started my Ayurvedic journey, and while I still struggle to maintain perfect balance – especially during Diwali festivities on 14/11/2020 – I'm more aware of my body and its needs. I incorporate Ayurvedic principles into my daily routine, like drinking warm water with lemon in the morning and practicing mindful eating. Ayurveda isn't just a treatment; it's a lifestyle, a way of connecting with my inner self and finding harmony in the chaos of urban life. I plan to revisit Dr. Nair for a follow-up consultation on 26/01/2024. Maybe then, I'll finally master the art of balancing my doshas, just like Aaji always did.
